title: 108_s2086
content: The "Abandoned Mine Land Reclamation Reform Act of 2004" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 by redesignating paragraphs and making conforming amendments. Section 3 addresses reclamation fees. Section 402 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to adjust various subsections, including reducing certain numbers and fees. In subsection (g), changes are made to grant allocations to ensure compliance by States and Indian tribes. The Secretary must ensure that States and Indian tribes adhere to specified priorities until certification is made. Changes are made to grant allocations to ensure compliance. The Secretary shall allocate funds under specified conditions, including reallocated amounts from section 411(h)(3) in addition to initial allocations. Qualified hydrologic units are defined in the context. A "unit" is a hydrologic unit significantly affected by acid mine drainage from coal mining, eligible for fund expenditure under section 404, and subject to state expenditures to abate and treat acid mine drainage. States with approved abandoned mine reclamation programs under section 405 may receive and retain funds. States with approved abandoned mine reclamation programs under section 405 may retain up to 10 percent of annual grants for acid mine drainage abatement and treatment if funds are deposited in a state-established fund. The funds must be used for comprehensive abatement and treatment within affected hydrologic units. In compliance with priorities, States and Indian tribes can use grants for specified projects before completing reclamation projects. The Secretary must ensure grant awards of at least $2,000,000 are made. The Secretary must ensure grant awards of at least $2,000,000 are made annually to each State, including Tennessee, and each Indian tribe. SEC. 4. OBJECTIVES OF FUND. Section 403 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to focus on health and safety, removing references to general welfare and adjusting water supply restoration provisions. In subsection (c), amendments require approval of the Secretary. SEC. 5 amends Section 406 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977, authorizing appropriations to the Secretary of Agriculture. SEC. 6 modifies liens under the Act. SEC. 7 pertains to certification. Section 411 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to include provisions for State Share for Certified States and Indian Tribes, defining qualified and non-qualified states or tribes based on certification and availability of public domain land for leasing under the Mineral Leasing Act. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to include provisions for State Share for Certified States and Indian Tribes. Qualified states and tribes are defined based on certification and availability of public domain land for leasing under the Mineral Leasing Act. Payments will be made to qualified states and tribes from amounts paid into the Treasury, on a proportional basis. The Secretary of the Interior will use funds from the Abandoned Mine Land Reclamation Reform Act of 2004 to make payments to non-qualified States and Indian tribes by December 31, 2004. The payment will be proportional to the unappropriated amount allocated to each State or tribe. The Secretary of the Interior will use funds from the Abandoned Mine Land Reclamation Reform Act of 2004 to make payments to non-qualified States and Indian tribes by December 31, 2004. The total amount of payments under this paragraph shall not exceed $65,000,000 and will be administered in the same manner as payments under the Mineral Leasing Act. Amounts allocated to States or tribes that are paid to qualified entities will be reallocated for grants. The total amount of payments under the Abandoned Mine Land Reclamation Reform Act of 2004 shall not exceed $65,000,000 and will be administered in the same manner as payments under the Mineral Leasing Act. Amounts allocated to States or tribes that are paid to qualified entities will be reallocated for grants under section 402(g)(5). SEC. 8. IMPLEMENTATION. Transition Rules regarding the availability of allocated amounts and interest under the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 for fiscal year 2005 and beyond. The Secretary of the Interior will review additions to the inventory under the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act made after December 31, 1998, to ensure their accuracy. The Secretary of the Interior will review additions to the inventory under the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act to ensure accuracy and remove any land or water that no longer meets specified criteria. Section 528(2) of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act is amended to exclude government financing under title IV. Section 510(e) is extended to 2014 for remining authority, with a savings clause preserving coal remining provisions.
